ExpSyntax.val: 'DV03: How Can I Dynamically Set the Order of the Retrieved Records in a Task?'

Text.val: This task writes to two text BLOBS, then reads them into a memory table.
This reads in the blob, using a ':' as a delimiter
In this task, the Index is hard coded. On the line above, you can see that the Index is set to '4'.
In this task, the Index is passed in as an Expression. Note that the ''INDEX literal is used. It is not
a good idea to use the index number directly, as the index number might change in the future.
A parameter is used for a couple of reasons. First, it forces the Subform to refresh when the Index is changed.
Also, it is common to call a separate program in this kind of circumstance, and in that case the Index would
At first glance, this looks like the Index is hard-coded. However, if you look at Task->Sort (Ctrl+T)
you will see that it is actually sorted by first and last name ... a sort for which there is no
built-in Index. Yet the task appears to run as fast as the others. Task Sorts can run very
efficiently, especially if there are not huge numbers of records. They are particularly good for
creating reports, and can be used to avoid the need for an intermediate memory table.
In this task the user can choose other options for sorting the table.
To allow these options, Task Properties->Options Tab->Options was set to Yes, and the
Index Change and Sorting Options are also set to Yes.
To allow sorting by column, each column control Sortable property is also set to Yes.
User sorting is very fast for smaller Data sources. However, it can be slower for rather large or inefficient Data sources.

Text.valUnicode: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}{\f1\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;\red255\green0\blue128;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.15.1515;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\cf1\b\f0\fs20 Any task also has the potential to be sorted interactively by the user. Click on one line to ensure this task is in focus, then try: \par \par 1. Changing the Index (\cf2 Ctrl+K\cf1 ). Notice that the Task Sort coded here shows up as an index choice.\par \par 2. Creating your own sort (\cf2 Ctrl+T\cf1 ) at runtime. Note that the First Name Task Sort created in this program also shows up on the list.\par \par 3. Clicking on the\cf2 table header\cf1 to change the sort order.\par \par \i\f1 Note:\i0\f0 The User Functionality component has a configurable interface for end-user sort options.\par }
